titleStmt.title: Transcription 2: 'Aingil Dé dom dhín' (BL, MS Egerton 2899)

availability.p: For internal use by the Faclair na Gàidhlig/DASG projects.

note.p: London, British Library, MS Egerton 2899, consists of a 14th-century psalter and a 15th-century (?) martyrology owned by the Campbells of Glenorchy through the 16th to the 18th century. In around 1500, 'Aingil Dé dom dhín', a Middle Gaelic verse lorica invoking the seven archangels and the twelve apostles, was inscribed on the flyleaf. On the whole, beyond names of angels and apostles, it consists of praise of their virtues and allusions to the dangers against which they protect the poet. In terms of language, there are some interesting early specimens and also some distinctive scribal traits that merit further investigation as possible examples of Scottish dialectal influence.

summary.p: 'Aingil Dé dom dhín' is a lorica, invoking the protection of the seven archangels (one for each day of the week; qq 1–18) and the twelve apostles, praising their merits, and alluding to the dangers from which through them the dovotee is preserved (qq 19-30). O'Nolan (1912: 253) suggests that these might have originally been two separate poems, as the section on the archangels closes with a dúnad. Some manuscripts attribute the poem to Colum Cille (Flower 1926: 24) but these are all late witnesses. Such an ascription is absent from earlier manuscripts, including Egerton 2899, and there is nothing in the text itself to particularly support it. It does, however, have a tendency to be selected by early scribes interested in Columban material (.i.e. the present scribe and the compilers of Laud Misc. 615)

msItem.title: Aingeal de dom dhin
msItem.note: The only edition of the text (which does not draw on Egerton 2899) is that of Thomas O'Nolan (1912). Flower (1926: 23–24) comments briefly upon it in his entry on Egerton 2899 in his Catalogue of Irish Manuscripts in the British Museum: Vol. 2. Ronald Black (2017: §128) repeats some of the essential details from O'Nolan and Flower and comments on the hand in the context of its contribution to Edinburgh, NLS, Adv. MS 72.1.31 (Black 2011: NLS Adv. MS 72.1.31). Any further extant work on the text is yet to be identified.

physDesc.p: Despite being intended as the manuscripts flyleaf, the page (fol. iiir) on which the text of interest is transcribed has not suffered any damage. Problems with legibility are thus minimal. The poem is laid out in a single column, with one quatrain per manuscript line.

supportDesc.foliation: Modern folitation; the poem is inscribed on what was intended to be the flyleaf.
supportDesc.condition: The condition is very good; the entire text is perfectly legible.

layoutDesc.p: Single column; one quatrain per line.

summary.p: According to Flower (1926: 23), Egerton 2899 began life in the 14th century as a Latin Psalter, to which a Martyrology was later added in the late 15th- or early 16th-century. 'Aingil Dé dom dhín' was probably added around 1500. The manuscript seems to have been owned by the Campbells of Glenorchy during this period and remained in the possession of a branch of the family (the Earls of Breadalbane) in the 18th century.

About a century later, the psalter was joined by a tabulated martyrology. The latter’s emphasis is on Scottish saints, some very local to Argyll. This, combined with an inscription implying that the manuscript was the property of Colin Campbell, Laird of Glenorchy (d. 1523), and a 18th-century bookplate of his descendants, the Earls of Breadalbane suggests an Argyll provenance for the gathering containing the martyrology. 'Aingil Dé dom dhín' would have been added in this context (around 1500). Technically, the psalter could be from elsewhere.
The manuscript was purchased for the British Museum's collections from Sotheby's in February 1912. How it came to be up for sale is unclear.

revisionDesc.change: Revised text in response to feedback
